Expectation1: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation1: A minor UI glitch occasionally shows up but has an easy workaround
Situation2: Savings are set aside and friends are going this season.
Story: I stared at the bug report on my screen, the same minor UI glitch that had been popping up for weeks. It wasn’t critical—users could refresh and move on—but QA kept flagging it, and my manager wanted it fixed before the next release. I knew it would take a few late nights to track down the root cause, and the pressure was mounting. At the same time, my friends were finalizing their plans for Hajj. We’d been saving for years, and this season, everything had finally lined up: the funds, the time, the group. My heart ached at the thought of missing this once-in-a-lifetime journey, but I also felt the weight of responsibility at work. My team was counting on me, and I didn’t want to let them down. The expectations from both sides pressed in, and I found myself torn, caught between my duty to my faith and my commitment to my job, unsure which path to choose.
